awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Palladium-Catalyzed C-H Activation/C-C Cross-Coupling of CH4 Hydrates and Plasma using Cyclodextrin Ligand in Multiphase Microsystems
awd_abstract_narration:
1453062 - Hartman

Science and engineering innovations over the last decade have enabled domestic natural gas resources that could sustain the U.S.'s energy, materials, commodity, pharmaceutical, and fine chemicals processing infrastructure. Natural gas, water science, and their symbiosis are keys to sustainability, and novel, economical approaches to the use of natural gas in organic synthesis at moderate temperatures (<200 degC) remains a challenge. The physics and the chemistry of water and methane (i.e., the largest component fraction of natural gas) have relevance in the atmospheric and planetary sciences. Massive quantities of natural gas are entrapped in crystalline water throughout the world, from the deep seabed to beneath the polar ice regions. Natural gas has merit for its use in organic synthesis but the challenges are in the controlled activation of carbon-hydrogen bonds of methane at moderate temperatures and their functionalization via carbon-carbon cross-coupling with aryl heteroatoms. This project involves the synergy of the five sciences: 

1) CH4 hydrates/plasma, 
2) cyclodextrin (CD) catalysis, 
3) palladium-catalyzed C-H activation/C-C crosscoupling,
4) microreaction engineering, and 
5) multiphase microfluidics with online analytics. 

If successful, this research could reduce the cost of current synthetic methodologies of Pd-catalyzed methylations of aryl heteroatoms for fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals by at least an order of magnitude. The resulting scientific discoveries will broadly impact aqueous natural gas technology, but they will also advance chemical engineering education.  The project will accomplish two K-12 educational goals beyond affecting the undergraduate and the graduate-level chemical reaction engineering curricula that the PI teaches: 1) inspire science and mathematics students to pursue careers in chemical engineering, and 2) innovate approaches to remotely involve students with chemical engineering research. The PI has already established a partnership with the Alabama School of Fine Arts, Birmingham, AL where he is mentoring a K-12 senior for the second year towards the completion of his research thesis. The knowledge created will be disseminated through works of art in both the science and the visual arts they generate. Students enrolled in the Alabama School of Fine Arts are commonly gifted in the visual arts, and thus each student the PI advises will express the chemical engineering knowledge they learn by touring exhibitions at the Birmingham Art Walk, the Alabama School of Fine Arts, and the posting of artwork photographs on the PI's laboratory website. The outcomes are anticipated to be innovations that discover the science of natural gas in aqueous systems, a K-12 educational component that broadly outreaches beyond the campus boarders, and ultimately the advancement of natural gas utilization in a broad cross-section of society.

Cyclodextrins (alpha-, beta-, and gamma-CD's), both naturally occurring and synthetically prepared organic inclusion compounds, are known to stabilize CH4 in liquid water and to catalyzed CH4 hydrate formation with molecular diffusion often controlling both processes. Molecular-level understanding acquired via the microreaction engineering of inclusion compounds and their complexes in C-H activation/C-C cross-coupling could advance the versatility of natural gas as an economical feedstock for multiphase organic synthesis. The understanding will be learned by i) innovating microsystems with online analytics for continuous multiphase C-C cross-couplings of CH4, ii) discovering the Pd-catalyzed C-C cross-coupling of CH4 stored in hydrates with aryl heteroatoms at organic-liquid water interfaces using alpha-, beta-, and gamma-CD's, iii) discovering the Pd-catalyzed C-C cross-coupling of ionized CH4 with aryl heteroatoms at cold plasma-liquid water interfaces, and iv) elucidating the catalytic cycle(s) that control the C-C cross-couplings. The project couples the PI's decade of experiences studying inorganic inclusion compounds in his doctoral research, innovating science and technology that are enabling the US to secure natural gas in his post-graduate career, researching microchemical systems for organic synthesis in his postdoctoral research, and building his academic laboratory on aqueous methane conversion with discoveries on gas hydrates and hydrophilic organic synthesis.

por.por_cntn:
An investigation of catalysts and new methodologies for methane activation, made possible by the NSF, generated unique intellectual merits.  Methane activation catalysis and reaction engineering has the potential to play a major role in the world's economy, energy, and the environment.  Firstly, microfluidics with in situ Raman spectroscopy were discovered a useful laboratory method for characterization of pressurized methane-water interfaces in confinement.  Next, the use of in situ Raman spectroscopy was explored to quantify the solubility of methane-cyclodextrin coordinated complexes in a multiphase gas-aqueous medium that would otherwise render methane insoluble.  Building on those discoveries, two catalytic complexes of cyclodextrin were studied to assess their potential for carbon-carbon bond formations with methane under mild conditions in aqueous-organic reaction mixtures.  The first catalyst, a palladium-beta-cyclodextrin complex, was found to catalyze a model Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling with oxidative addition as the rate determining reaction step in the mechanism, while the estimated activation energy was less than the state-of-the-art of the free energy barrier of the transition state with conventional phosphine ligands in lieu of cyclodextrin.  The second catalyst, an aryl amine-palladium-beta-cyclodextrin complex, was observed to catalyze the same reaction with a first order rate dependence on the oxidative addition, yet at a higher activation energy and in the range of conventional phosphine ligands.  These kinetics studies exemplified the potential for cooperative catalysis where two transition metals on one cyclodextrin cup can catalyze together a versatile chemical reaction.  In an effort to study unconventional methane activation catalysis, a dielectric barrier discharge microplasmatron was designed, modeled, and tested to methylate an organometallic complex.  The formation of methyl radicals from the non-thermal methane plasmas were confirmed by in situ optical emission spectroscopy measurements, which created a new experimental method for the study of plasma catalytic reactions.  The findings undergird the exciting prospects of methane plasmas in organometallic synthesis, which remains a vastly unexplored area of chemical catalysis.  In the context plasma physics, this work demonstrated that "flash chemistry", or reactions that occur in short time scales, can be studied with multiphase microplasmatrons, where transport limitations in conventional reactor designs often mask the reaction kinetics and mechanisms.

The project also generated unique broader impacts on education and society.  The knowledge reported in our NSF products could be applied by industry for utilization of natural gas as a reactant in homogeneous organometallic chemistry.  The techniques reported herein could be used to synthesize or to discover new catalysts with methane atmospheric nonthermal plasmas.  The number of reaction steps and intermediary workups could also be reduced by the direct activation of methane via plasmas, and in turn decrease the chemical waste generated and energy consumed.  The work could also expand the scope of naturally derived catalysts for useful cross-couplings in chemicals manufacturing.  The funding has had a positive impact on education by introducing the new concepts into undergraduate and graduate chemical engineering courses taught by the principal investigator.  Four graduate students, three undergraduates, and three K-12 students were provided opportunities to complete chemical engineering research in this project.  A K-12 partnership with Brooklyn Technical High School was established and a senior thesis program also developed.  The project further advanced the infrastructure of the PI's laboratory by providing safe methods for the study of catalysis using flammable gases and electricity.  To date, the project's results have been disseminated through two masters theses, one undergraduate thesis, three K-12 senior theses, four journal publications (and two in preparation), eighteen conference presentations, seventeen invited academic seminars, five invited industry seminars, seven educational aids or curricula, and one alumni and three community outreach events.  Improvement in public knowledge of the research has been accomplished.  NYU Tandon Marketing and Communications have broadcast multiple news stories/press releases on the project, in addition to news stories worldwide.  The PI's laboratory also maintains a website and Twitter account (@HartmanLab) where news stories and journal publications of the results were posted on the world-wide-web/social media.  Finally, the research results were presented in the NYU Tandon School of Engineering Research Expo, NYU Alumni Day, and the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair where members of the NYC greater community had the opportunity to learn about the project and its societal importance.

An investigation of catalysts and new methodologies for methane activation, made possible by the NSF, generated unique intellectual merits.  Methane activation catalysis and reaction engineering has the potential to play a major role in the world's economy, energy, and the environment.  Firstly, microfluidics with in situ Raman spectroscopy were discovered a useful laboratory method for characterization of pressurized methane-water interfaces in confinement.  Next, the use of in situ Raman spectroscopy was explored to quantify the solubility of methane-cyclodextrin coordinated complexes in a multiphase gas-aqueous medium that would otherwise render methane insoluble.  Building on those discoveries, two catalytic complexes of cyclodextrin were studied to assess their potential for carbon-carbon bond formations with methane under mild conditions in aqueous-organic reaction mixtures.  The first catalyst, a palladium-beta-cyclodextrin complex, was found to catalyze a model Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling with oxidative addition as the rate determining reaction step in the mechanism, while the estimated activation energy was less than the state-of-the-art of the free energy barrier of the transition state with conventional phosphine ligands in lieu of cyclodextrin.  The second catalyst, an aryl amine-palladium-beta-cyclodextrin complex, was observed to catalyze the same reaction with a first order rate dependence on the oxidative addition, yet at a higher activation energy and in the range of conventional phosphine ligands.  These kinetics studies exemplified the potential for cooperative catalysis where two transition metals on one cyclodextrin cup can catalyze together a versatile chemical reaction.  In an effort to study unconventional methane activation catalysis, a dielectric barrier discharge microplasmatron was designed, modeled, and tested to methylate an organometallic complex.  The formation of methyl radicals from the non-thermal methane plasmas were confirmed by in situ optical emission spectroscopy measurements, which created a new experimental method for the study of plasma catalytic reactions.  The findings undergird the exciting prospects of methane plasmas in organometallic synthesis, which remains a vastly unexplored area of chemical catalysis.  In the context plasma physics, this work demonstrated that "flash chemistry", or reactions that occur in short time scales, can be studied with multiphase microplasmatrons, where transport limitations in conventional reactor designs often mask the reaction kinetics and mechanisms.

The project also generated unique broader impacts on education and society.  The knowledge reported in our NSF products could be applied by industry for utilization of natural gas as a reactant in homogeneous organometallic chemistry.  The techniques reported herein could be used to synthesize or to discover new catalysts with methane atmospheric nonthermal plasmas.  The number of reaction steps and intermediary workups could also be reduced by the direct activation of methane via plasmas, and in turn decrease the chemical waste generated and energy consumed.  The work could also expand the scope of naturally derived catalysts for useful cross-couplings in chemicals manufacturing.  The funding has had a positive impact on education by introducing the new concepts into undergraduate and graduate chemical engineering courses taught by the principal investigator.  Four graduate students, three undergraduates, and three K-12 students were provided opportunities to complete chemical engineering research in this project.  A K-12 partnership with Brooklyn Technical High School was established and a senior thesis program also developed.  The project further advanced the infrastructure of the PI's laboratory by providing safe methods for the study of catalysis using flammable gases and electricity.  To date, the project's results have been disseminated through two masters theses, one undergraduate thesis, three K-12 senior theses, four journal publications (and two in preparation), eighteen conference presentations, seventeen invited academic seminars, five invited industry seminars, seven educational aids or curricula, and one alumni and three community outreach events.  Improvement in public knowledge of the research has been accomplished.  NYU Tandon Marketing and Communications have broadcast multiple news stories/press releases on the project, in addition to news stories worldwide.  The PI's laboratory also maintains a website and Twitter account (@HartmanLab) where news stories and journal publications of the results were posted on the world-wide-web/social media.  Finally, the research results were presented in the NYU Tandon School of Engineering Research Expo, NYU Alumni Day, and the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair where members of the NYC greater community had the opportunity to learn about the project and its societal importance.
